title: ECRP05: Sources of linguistic control over eye movements
abstractText:
This proposal attaches teams of eye movement researchers in Dundee and Edinburgh to a pan-European Collaborative Project involving researchers in Potsdam and Salzburg. 

Aims:

  • To collect predictability and word frequency norms for a range of texts and arrive at an understanding of how these properties affect the readerâ€™s inspection strategy;
  • To examine individual differences in reading skill and other relevant cognitive functions and show how these features can be represented in a computational model;
  • To examine the processing consequences of varying the reader's goals, and the effects of varying the text genre (eg prose vs poetry);
  • To develop a model of "memory-guided" eye movements (ie to remote words, not visible as targets) and link this to individual differences in reinspection strategy;
  • To examine individuals with developmental or acquired dyslexias of various kinds, with the aim of producing models which, when impaired in various ways, replicate the reading failure at different levels;
  • To examine the consequences for eye movement control of the fact that the human fovea is vertically divided, with the initial projection of the left and right parts of a fixated word giving rise to a degree of independent hemispheric processing.
